meanings.definition: To grade or evaluate (something) too highly
meanings.sent1: The teacher was overgrading the students' essays, giving everyone an A+.
meanings.sent2: She realized she had been overgrading the quality of the used car she was trying to sell.
meanings.sent3: The chef overgrading the taste of his new dish made everyone laugh.
meanings.sent4: Her optimism overgraded the situation, making it seem better than it was.
meanings.sent5: Overgrading the importance of the meeting made him anxious and nervous.

meanings.definition: The act of assigning a grade that is too high
meanings.sent1: The overgrading of the test results led to confusion among the students.
meanings.sent2: The professor's overgrading of the final exams caused a lot of discussions among the faculty.
meanings.sent3: The overgrading of the cake's sweetness made it too sugary for anyone to enjoy.
meanings.sent4: The overgrading of the movie's plot left the audience disappointed and unsatisfied.
meanings.sent5: The overgrading of the painting's value resulted in a high price at the auction.

meanings.definition: The process of assessing something as better than it actually is
meanings.sent1: Her overgrading of her own abilities led to unrealistic expectations.
meanings.sent2: The company's overgrading of the product's performance misled many customers.
meanings.sent3: The overgrading of the weather forecast made everyone pack unnecessary items for the trip.
meanings.sent4: His overgrading of his opponent's skills cost him the match in the end.
meanings.sent5: The overgrading of the hotel's amenities left the guests disappointed upon arrival.
